title: François Colin de Blamont
text:
François Colin de Blamont (22 November 1690 – 14 February 1760) was a French composer of the <a href="Baroque%20music">Baroque</a> era.
Born at <a href="Versailles%20%28city%29">Versailles</a> as François Colin, he served as a royal musician and was eventually ennobled in 1750, his surname becoming "Colin de Blamont". He was the protégé of <a href="Michel%20Richard%20Delalande">Michel Richard Delalande</a> and succeeded the latter as Master of the Chapelle Royale on his death in 1726. Blamont wrote <a href="motet">motet</a>s and <a href="cantata">cantata</a>s as well as stage works, including the <a href="opera">opera</a> "Les fêtes grecques et romaines", intended to be the first in a new genre, the "ballet héroïque", which would challenge the supremacy of the "<a href="op%C3%A9ra-ballet">opéra-ballet</a>".
